meanings.def: a set of rooms for living in, usually on one floor of a building
examples: They're renting a furnished flat on the third floor.
to buy/sell a flat
in a flat Do you live in a flat or a house?
a basement/ground-floor/top-floor flat
a two-bedroom flat
The park was surrounded by high-rise flats and office blocks.
a new block of flats
Many large old houses have been converted into flats.
Children from the flats (= the block of flats) across the street were playing outside.
Do you think that the council could find me another flat?
Even the prices of small bachelor flats are unbelievable.
I'll meet you back at your flat.
She lives in the top flat.
The flat is located in a modern development.
The landlady found they had been illegally subletting the flat.
The musician rented a flat in a fashionable area of London.
They live in the next flat.
We got her a flat in the same block as ours.

meanings.def: the flat level part of something
examples: He beat on the door with the flat of his hand.
the flat of a sword

meanings.def: an area of low flat land, especially near water
examples: salt flats
These birds live on the coastal flats.
mud and sand flats rich in animal life

meanings.def: the season for racing horses on flat ground with no jumps
a note played a semitone lower than the note that is named. The written symbol is (♭).
examples: There are no sharps or flats in the key of C major.

meanings.def: a tyre that has lost air, usually because of a hole
examples: We got a flat on the way home.
We had to stop to fix a flat.

meanings.def: a vertical section of scenery used on a theatre stage
shoes with a very low heel
examples: a pair of flats

meanings.def: on level ground, without hills or jumps (= for example in horse racing)
examples: Overtaking the next cyclist on an Alpine climb is a dozen times harder than on the flat.

idioms.def: on level ground, without hills or jumps (= for example in horse racing)
examples: Overtaking the next cyclist on an Alpine climb is a dozen times harder than on the flat.

meanings.def: having a level surface, not curved or sloping, and without holes or any bits sticking out
examples: low buildings with flat roofs
I need a flat surface to write on.
A large flat screen was mounted on the wall.
We found a large flat rock to sit on.
People used to think the earth was flat.
a large, deep dish with a flat bottom
Exercise is the only way to get a flat stomach after having a baby.

meanings.def: without any slopes or hills
examples: The road stretched ahead across the flat landscape.
The desert was flat, mile after mile.
He reached a flatter section of land near the river.
the flat plains of northern Germany

meanings.def: calm and without waves
examples: The sails hung limply in the flat calm (= conditions at sea when there is no wind and the water is completely level).
The sea was almost completely flat.
The water was dead flat, like a mirror.

meanings.def: broad but not very high
examples: Chapattis are a kind of flat Indian bread.
flat shoes (= with no heels or very low ones)
(figurative) The company's organizational structure was kept deliberately flat, with only three levels of hierarchy.

meanings.def: not exciting; not feeling or showing interest or enthusiasm
examples: He felt very flat after his friends had gone home.
It was a curiously flat note on which to end the election campaign.
Life will seem a bit flat without you.
She was feeling very flat after the excitement of the flight.

meanings.def: not showing much emotion; not changing much in tone
examples: Her voice was flat and expressionless.
He spoke in a flat Midlands accent.
He went on in a flat tone.

meanings.def: very smooth, with no contrast between light and dark, and giving no impression of depth
examples: Acrylic paints can be used to create large, flat blocks of colour.

meanings.def: not very successful because very little is being sold; not changing or increasing
examples: The housing market has been flat for months.
Interest rates have remained flat.

meanings.def: not allowing discussion or argument; definite
examples: Her request was met with a flat refusal.
He gave a flat ‘No!’ to one reporter's question.
These results are in flat contradiction to the theory of relativity.

meanings.def: used after the name of a note to mean a note a semitone lower
examples: That note should be B flat, not B.

meanings.def: below the correct pitch (= how high or low a note sounds)
examples: The high notes were slightly flat.

meanings.def: no longer having bubbles in it; not fresh
examples: The soda was warm and had gone flat.

meanings.def: unable to supply any more electricity
not containing enough air, usually because of a hole
with no natural raised curves under the feet
that is my final decision and I will not change my mind
examples: You can't go and that's flat!

meanings.def: completely flat
examples: The country around here is as flat as a pancake.

meanings.def: very confused, worried or excited
examples: Her resignation put her colleagues in a spin.

meanings.def: in bed because you are ill
examples: She's been flat on her back for over a week now.
(figurative) The UK market was flat on its back (= business was very bad).

idioms.def: that is my final decision and I will not change my mind
examples: You can't go and that's flat!
The country around here is as flat as a pancake.
Her resignation put her colleagues in a spin.

idioms.def: in bed because you are ill
examples: She's been flat on her back for over a week now.
(figurative) The UK market was flat on its back (= business was very bad).

meanings.def: spread out in a level, straight position, especially against another surface
examples: Lie flat and breathe deeply.
They pressed themselves flat against the tunnel wall as the train approached.
I can't get this material to lie flat.

meanings.def: in a definite and direct way
examples: She told me flat she would not speak to me again.
I made them a reasonable offer but they turned it down flat.

meanings.def: lower than the correct pitch (= how high or low a note sounds)
examples: He sings flat all the time.

meanings.def: if a joke, a story, or an event falls flat, it completely fails to make people laugh or to have the effect that was intended
examples: Without Jem, the whole evening would have fallen flat.

meanings.def: to fall so that you are lying on your front
to fail completely, usually in an embarrassing way
examples: His next television venture fell flat on its face.

meanings.def: completely broke (= without money)
as fast or as hard as possible
examples: Workers are working flat out to meet the rise in demand for new cars.

meanings.def: in a definite and direct way; completely
examples: I told him flat out ‘No’.
It's a 30-year mortgage we just flat out can't handle.

meanings.def: used with an expression of time to say that something happened or was done very quickly, in no more than the time stated
examples: They changed the wheel in three minutes flat (= in only three minutes).

idioms.def: if a joke, a story, or an event falls flat, it completely fails to make people laugh or to have the effect that was intended
examples: Without Jem, the whole evening would have fallen flat.

idioms.def: to fall so that you are lying on your front
examples: His next television venture fell flat on its face.

idioms.def: as fast or as hard as possible
examples: Workers are working flat out to meet the rise in demand for new cars.
I told him flat out ‘No’.
It's a 30-year mortgage we just flat out can't handle.

idioms.def: used with an expression of time to say that something happened or was done very quickly, in no more than the time stated
examples: They changed the wheel in three minutes flat (= in only three minutes).

meanings.def: to live in or share a flat
examples: My sister Zoe flats in Auckland.
